title: Madawaska—Acadian Light-Heavy

thumbnail.alt_text: A work made of oil on hardboard.

description: “I have for the first time since 1922 a real live model a magnificent young feller. . . . His body is so fine and dear I could work almost without end from him.” So wrote Marsden Hartley about Lionel Daigle, a French-Canadian boxer from the town of Madawaska, Maine, who modeled for a series of paintings by the artist. A Maine native himself, Hartley drew upon local types at this time to create a mythic view of the state’s inhabitants as rugged individualists. Hartley delighted in painting the man’s body, which allowed him to express his own sexuality. He emphasized Daigle’s strong physique, exaggerating his anatomy and originally painting him nude (subsequently adding the brief covering). Ironically, critics in the 1940s applauded the work as a display of heteronormative masculinity.
inscriptions: Signed, inscribed, and dated verso: Madawaska--Acadian / Light-Heavy / Marsden Hartley / 1940.
publication_history: Judith A. Barter et al., American Modernism at the Art Institute of Chicago, From World War I to 1955, (Chicago: Art Institute of Chicago/Yale University Press, 2009), cat. 116.
exhibition_history: Whitney Museum of American Art, Marsden Hartley, Mar. 4–May 25, 180; The Art Institute, June 10–Aug. 3, 1980; Fort Worth, Amon Carter Museum of Western Art, Sept. 5–Oct. 26, 1980; Berkeley, University Art Museum, University of California, Nov. 12, 1980–Jan. 4, 1981, cat. 89. New York, Salander O'Reilly Galleries, Marsden Hartley: The Late Figure Works, May 30–June 30, 1990. Turin, Italy, Lingotto, Arte Americana, Jan.–Mar. 1992. Hartford, Wadsworth Atheneum, Marsden Hartley: American Modernist, Jan. 18–Apr. 20, 2003; Washington, DC, Phillips Collection, June 7–Sept. 7, 2003; Kansas City, Nelson–Atkins Museum of Art, Oct. 11, 2003–Jan. 11, 2004. Paris, Musee d'Orsay, Masculine/Masculine: The Naked Man in Art from 1800 to the Present Day, Sept. 23, 2013–Jan. 2, 2014. Metropolitan Museum of Art, Marsden Hartley's Maine, Mar. 15–June 18, 2017; Waterville, Maine, Colby College Museum of Art, July 8–Nov. 12, 2017, cat. 13. Humlebæk, Denmark, Louisiana Museum of Modern Art, Marsden Hartley: The Earth is All I Know of Wonder, Sept. 19, 2019–Jan. 19, 2020, cat. 91 (ill.)
provenance_text: Estate of the artist (no. 94); sold to Eva Lee Gallery, Grand Neck, NY, 1960; Alan Gallery, New York, by 1962; sold to A. James Speyer (1913–1986), Chicago, 1962; bequeathed to the Art Institute of Chicago, 1987.
